gurmukhi: sovq QI jnu lwj kI nId mY lwj kI nId qjI Ab jwgI ] jwko munI nih AMq lhY ieh qwhI so Kyl krY bfBwgI ]553]
transliteration: Sovat Thijan(u) Laaj Kineed Mai Laaj Kineed Tajiab Jaagee|| Jaako Mounndnah(i) Ant Lahai Eh Taahiso Khel Darai  Badbhaagee||553||
translation: Till now she had been absorbed in the sleep of shyness, but that shyness also abandoned sleep and awoke; he, whose mystery has not been comprehended by the sages, the fortunate Radhika is absorbed in playing with him.553.
Speech of Krishna addressed to Radha:

gurmukhi: kiRSn rwiDkw sMg khXo Aiq hI ibhis kY bwq ] Kylhu gwvhu pRym so sun sm kMcn gwq ]554]
transliteration: Krishan Raadhikaa San Kahyo At(i) Hibihast(i) Kai Baat|| Kheloh Gadvoh Prem So Soun Sam Kanchanndgadt||554||
translation: Krishna said smilingly to Radha, “O dear of the body of gold! You keep on playing smilingly.”554.

gurmukhi: kiRSn bwq sun rwiDkw Aiq hI ibhis kY cIq ] rws ibKY gwvn lgI gÍwrn so imil gIq ]555]
transliteration: Krishan Baat Soun Raadhikaa At(i) Hibihas(i) Kai Cheet|| Raas Bikhai Gadvan Lagigvaaran So Mil(i) Geet||555||
translation: Hearing the words of Krishna, Radha, smilingly in her mind, began to sing alongwith the gopis in the amorous play.555.

gurmukhi: cMdRBgw Aru cMdRmuKI imlkY biRKBwn suqw sMg gwvY ] sorT swrMg su`D mlwr iblwvl BIqr qwn bswvY ]
transliteration: Channdrabhagad Ar(u) Channdramoukhimil-kai Brikhbhaan Soutaa San Gadvai|| Sorath Saaran Suddh Malaar Bilaaval Basaavai||
translation: Chandarbhaga and Chandarmukhi began to sing alongwith Radha and raised the tunes of Sorath, Sarang, Shuddh Malhar and Bilawal;

gurmukhi: rIJ rhI biRj hUM kI qRIAw soaU rIJ rhY Dun jo sun pwvY ] so sun kY ienpY ihq kY bn iqAwg miRgI miRg Aau cil AwvY ]556]
transliteration: Reejh Rahibrij Hoon Kitreeaa Sooo Reejh Rahai Dhoun Jo Soun Paavai|| So Soun Kai In Pai Hit Kai Ban Tiaag Mrigimrig Au Chal(i) Aavai||556||
translation: The women of Braja were allured and whosoever listened to that tune, he was fascinated; listening to that voice, even the deer and does of the forest moved towards this side.556.

gurmukhi: iqn syNDr mwNg deI isr pY rs ko iqn so Aiq hI mn BIno ] bysr Awf kMTisrI Aru moiqisrI hUM ko swj nvIno ]
transliteration: Tin Sendhar Maan Daisir Pai Ras Ko Tin So At(i) Himan Bheeno|| Besar Aad Kanthsiriar(u) Mot(i) Sirihoun Ko Saaj Naveeno||
translation: The gopis filled their partings of the hair on the head with vermilion and their mind was filled with pleasure; they bedecked themselves with the nose-ornaments, necklaces and wreaths of pearls;

gurmukhi: BUKn AMg sBY sij suMdr AwNKn BIqr kwjr dIno ] qwhI su qy kib sXwm khY Bgvwn ko ic`q curwie kY lIno ]557]
transliteration: Bhookhanndan Sabhai Saj(i) Soundar Aankhan Bheetar Kaajar Deeno|| Taahisu Te Kabisyaam Kahai Bhagvaan Ko Chitt Churaae Kai Leeno||557||
translation: The gopis, adorning all their limbs with ornaments, applied antimony to their eyes; the poet Shyam says that in this way, they stole the mind of Lord Krishna.557.

gurmukhi: cMd kI cwNdnI mY kib sXwm jbY hir Kylin rws lgXo hY ] rwDy ko Awnn suMdr pyiK kY cwNd so qwhI ky bIc pgXo hY ]
transliteration: Channd Kichaandanimai Kabi Syaam Jabai Har(i) Khelan(i) Raas Lagyo Hai|| Raadhe Ko Aanan Soundar Pekh(i) Kai Chaand So Taahike Beech Pagyo Hai||
translation: When Krishna began to play in moonshine, the face of Radhika appeared to him like the moon; she store the heart of Krishna;

gurmukhi: hir ko iqn icq curwih lIXo su ikDo kib ko mn XO aumgXo hY ] nYnn ko rs dy iBlvw biRKBwn TgI Bgvwn TgXo hY ]558]
transliteration: Har(i) Ko Tin Chit Churaah(i) Leeyo Su Kidho Kab(i) Ko Man You Oumgyo Hai|| Nainan Ko Ras De Bhilvaa Brikhbhaan Thagibhagvaan Thagyo Hai||558||
translation: The poet has said that Radha, the daughter of Brish Bhan cheated Krishna with the deception of her eyes.558.

gurmukhi: ijh ko ipiK kY muiK mYn ljY ijh ko idK kY muiK cMdR ljY ] kib sXwm khy soaU Kylq hY sMg kwnHr ky suB swj sjY ]
transliteration: Jih Ko Pikh(i) Moukh(i) Main Lajai Jih Ko Dikh Kai Moukh(i) Channdra Lajai|| Kabi Syaam Kahe Sooo Khelat Hai San Kaahnar Ke Soubh Saaj Sajai||
translation: He, seeing whom the god of love and the moon feel shy, the poet Shyam says that the same Radha, adorning herself, is playing with Krishna;
